src: kʰa ɯ-ʁɤri kɯ-nɤʁaʁ tɤ-mu nɯra kɯ nɯ-sɤz-nɯmbjɯm smi cʰɯ-nɯ-βlɯ-nɯ pjɤ-ŋu
trs: Old women who were resting in front of the house were burning a fire to keep themselves warm.' (2002 qaCpa, 227)

src: tɯ-βɣo ɣɯ ɯ-tɕɯ cʰondɤre ɯ-me nɯra nɯ-ɕki tɕe, tɕe kɯ-wxti ra nɯ-ɕki ``a-pi" tu-kɯ-ti, kɯ-xtɕi ra nɯ-ɕki ``a-ʁi" tu-kɯ-ti ŋu.
trs: One's father's brother's sons and daughters, one calls the elder ones \forme{a-pi} `my elder sibling' and the younger ones \forme{a-ʁi} `my younger sibling'.' (140425 kWmdza01, 32)

src: jinde tʰam tɕe ``a-pi a-ʁi" tu-nɯ-ti-nɯ ŋu ma
trs: Nowadays (maternal parallel cousin) call (each other) \forme{a-pi} `my elder sibling' and  \forme{a-ʁi} `my younger sibling'(casually).' (140425 kWmdza01, 45)

src: tɤ-rpɯ nɯ kɯnɤ ``a-ftsa" tu-ti, tɤ-ɬaʁ nɯ kɯnɤ ``a-ftsa" tu-ti
trs: Both the maternal uncle and the maternal aunt call (their sister's children) \forme{a-ftsa}.'  (140425 kWmdza04, 20-21)

src: aʑo tɤ-tɕɯ a-pɯ-ŋu-a qʰe tɕe, a-xtɤɣ ɣɯ ɯ-rɟit nɯnɯra nɯ-ɕki a-mdɯ ŋu.
trs: If I were a man, I would call my brother's children \forme{a-mdɯ} `my parallel nephew'.' (140425 kWmdza01, 17)
Women do not have (any relative that can be called with the term) \forme{tɤ-mdɯ} `parallel nephew'. (140425 kWmdza02, 25)

src: nɯnɯtɕu tɕe tɕe li ``a-mdɯ" tu-tɯ-ti, woja, tɕʰeme ɯ-rɟit nɯ ``a-ftsa" tu-tɯ-ti, tɯ-mu tɯ-mu kɯ-naχtɕɯɣ cʰo kɯ-naχtɕɯɣ ŋu.
trs: (Question: How do \textsuperscript{♂}I address \forme{a-wa ɯ-xtɤɣ ɯ-ɣe ɯ-ɕki} my father's brother's grandchildren? Response:) `In that case, \textsuperscript{♂}you say \forme{a-mdɯ} `\textsuperscript{♂}my brother's son', in the case of a girl's child (FBDCh) you say \forme{a-ftsa} `my sister's son', like (siblings sharing) the same parents.' (elicitation, 2019-11-30)

src: aʑo a-rɟit ra kɯ (...) aʑo a-sqʰaj ɣɯ ɯ-rɟit ra nɯ-ɕki  tɕe ``a-mɤtsa" tu-ti-nɯ, nɯnɯra, ɣɯ nɯ-rɟit ra nɯ-ɕki qʰe li, ``a-mɤtsa" tu-nɯ-ti-nɯ
trs: My children (...) call my sister's children$_i$ \forme{a-mɤtsa}, and also called their$_i$ children \forme{a-mɤtsa}.' (140425 kWmdza01, 48-49)

src: tɯ-rpɯ ɣɯ ɯ-rɟit ɯ-ɕki tɕe ``a-rpɯ" tu-kɯ-ti, ɯ-ɣe ɯ-ɕki tɕe ``a-rpɯ" tu-kɯ-ti kɯ-ŋgrɤl ɲɯ-ŋu, iʑora kɯrɯ kɯ tɕe.
trs: One calls one's maternal uncle's children and his grandchildren \forme{a-rpɯ} `my maternal uncle', among us Tibetans.' (140425 kWmdza07, 2)

src: nɯ ɯ-pa pɯ-ari tɕe tɕe, a-wɤmɯ ɯ-ɣe pɯ-nɯ-ŋu, a-sqʰaj ɣɯ ɯ-ɣe pɯ-nɯ-ŋu tɕe aʑo tɤrcɯrca ``a-ɣe" tu-ti-a ɕti.
trs: In the (generation) below (that of one's nephews, see §\ref{sec:vertical.preverbs.time}), I say \forme{a-ɣe} `my grandchild' (to all grandnephews), whether they are my brother's grandchildren or my sister's granchildren.' (140425 kWmdza02, 16)

src: nɯnɯra tɕe tɯʑo sɤz a-pɯ-wxti-nɯ qʰe ``a-pi" tu-kɯ-ti, tɯʑo sɤz a-pɯ-xtɕi-nɯ qʰe ``a-ʁi" tu-kɯ-nɯ-ti ɕti. ``a-xtɤɣ" ra tu-o<nɯ>mɯ-ti-nɯ ɕti.
trs: Those (ego's husband's or wife's siblings), if they are elder than oneself, one calls them \forme{a-pi} `my elder sibling', if they are younger one calls them \forme{a-ʁi} `my younger sibling'. They also call each other \forme{a-xtɤɣ}`my brother' and the like.' (140425 kWmdza05, 8)

src: kɤndʑi-mɤtsa nɯni tɕe ci ku-pa-ndʑi kɯ-kʰɯ ɲɯ-ŋu, kɯ-ŋgrɤl ɲɯ-ŋu, mɤ-kɯ-ʁdɯɣ ɲɯ-ŋu.
trs: For two maternal parallel cousins, it is possible to get married, it is the usage, it is not wrong.' (140427 kWmdza stWnmW, 03)

src: kɤndʑi-xtɤɣ ɯ-rɟit nɯ tɤ-ŋu tɕe tɕe, ci kú-wɣ-pa maka mɤ-kɯ-kʰɯ ɲɯ-ŋu.
trs: As for brother's children, it is completely impossible for them to marry each other.' (140427 kWmdza stWnmW, 11)

src: aʑo nɯ praʁwɯ rɟitpa ŋu-a tɕe, a-rɟit ni praʁwɯ rɟitpa kɯnɤ kɯ-ɤ-rtsi ŋu-ndʑi,
trs: I am (Tshendzin) from the lineage of Praqwu, and (therefore) my two children also count as being from the lineage of Praqwu.' (140426 rJitpa, 4-5)

imt: \textsc{genr}.\textsc{poss}-mother side \textsc{dem} \textsc{aor}:\textsc{up}-\textsc{inv}-count \textsc{lnk} \textsc{genr}.\textsc{poss}-mother side lineage \textsc{ipfv}:\textsc{up}-\textsc{genr}:S/O-count be:\textsc{fact}  \textsc{genr}.\textsc{poss}-father side \textsc{dem} \textsc{aor}:\textsc{down}-count-\textsc{pl} \textsc{lnk} \textsc{genr}.\textsc{poss}-mother side lineage \textsc{dem} \textsc{ipfv}:\textsc{down}-count-\textsc{pl} be.\textsc{aff}:\textsc{fact}
src: tɯ-mu pɕoʁ nɯ tɤ́-wɣ-rtsɯz tɕe, tɯ-mu pɕoʁ rɟitpa tu-kɯ-rtsi ŋu, tɯ-wa pɕoʁ pa-rtsɯz-nɯ tɕe, li tɯ-wa pɕoʁ rɟitpa nɯ pjɯ-rtsi-nɯ ɕti
trs: When one counts from  one's mother's side, one is counted as being from the lineage on one mother's side, when people count from one's father's side (downwards), they count as being from one's father lineage.' (140426 rJitpa, 2-3)

src: tɯʑo tɕʰeme ɣɯ tɯ-rɟit nɯnɯ kɯ tɕe tɕe tɯ-wɤmɯ ra nɯ-rɟit nɯ-ɕki tɕe li ``a-rpɯ a-ɬaʁ"  tu-ti-nɯ kɯ-ra.
trs: One's children (\textsc{ego} being a women) call one's brother's children \forme{a-rpɯ} `my mother's brother' or \forme{a-ɬaʁ} `my mother's sister'. (140425 kWmdza01, 60-62)

src: nɤ-ɲi ɣɯ ɯ-ɣe kɯ tɕe tɕe, nɤj nɤ-ɕki ``a-rpɯ" tu-ti kɯ-ra ɕti.
trs: Your father's sister's grandchildren have to call you `my mother's brother'.' (elicitation 2019-11-30)
